awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this research project is to advance the understanding of boundary effects and their underlying mathematical structures. The project deals with three models stemming from statistical physics. First, the two-species totally asymmetric exclusion process, is a discrete version of a system of two coupled Burgers equations. The PI proposes to determine a conjectured new sub-leading exponent of this system and to investigate the properties of the phase diagram in the presence of boundary terms. The second objective is the establishment of a correspondence between boundary terms in the boundary conformal loop model and the XX- and XXZ- quantum spin chains with boundary operators. The third subject is a Markov chain describing a growing and fluctuating interface in the presence of a wall. The PI will determine the critical exponent of boundary avalanches and investigate the connection to the discrete Boussinesq equation. The PI will employ methods ranging from Bethe-Ansatz to conformal field theory, finite-size scaling and Monte-Carlo simulations. The above projects will provide important insights into the theory of critical phenomena in the presence of boundary terms. The project is focused on three important areas, namely the role of boundaries in phase diagrams of statistical models, the classification of all boundary terms preserving conformal invariance in boundary conformal field theories and the influence of boundaries on Markov processes. There is also evidence that the outcome of the project will have implications for the theory of quantum computing. 

Broader Impact. The PI, holding a joint appointment in mathematics and physics, is fostering the interdisciplinary dialogue between these two departments by discussing research projects with colleagues in both departments. She is also supervising a graduate student working on a joint research project with the chemistry department. The project broadens the representation of women in the sciences with the PI actively serving as a role model for women in mathematics and physics, and her involvement in "Women in Science" and "Women in Physics" initiatives. She participates in science fairs through the the Science K-12 Outreach Program at Purdue University. She was invited by the mathematics department to teach an interdisciplinary course as a distance learning class.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this proposal was to understand boundary effects in critical phenomena. Several different systems have been successfully studied, thus advancing the knowledge in several fields of science, like statistical physics, condensed matter physics and mathematics and fostering their cross-fertilization.

Specifically, we have contributed new results about the multi-species exclusion model, finding the dynamical critical exponent from a Bethe-Ansatz approach. The dynamical critical exponent describes the relation between the typical length scale and the typical time scale of the model and is the same for all models belonging to the same universality class. We also defined a new height model that describes the dynamics of the exclusion model in terms of coupled partial differential equations. These partial differential equations describe different types of dynamical behavior depending on the rates of the underlying hopping particle model. They can exhibit KPZ- type behavior, diffusive behavior or a mixture of both.

Furthermore, we have obtained new results about the behavior of boundary-touching avalanches in the raise and peel model which is a specific Markov type model from statistical mechanics. This model describes the growing and peeling of a surface that grows under specific stochastic rules by random deposition of particles (or tiles) from above. If certain conditions are fulfilled, surface avalanches occur that peel off a portion of the surface layer. We have studied avalanches touching the boundaries of this surface for the first time and found a new critical exponent and a parity effect, meaning that the parity of the number of tiles removed in the avalanche plays a role in the scaling behavior of wall-touching avalanches.

We also have investigated materials with a gyroid structure, a triply periodic minimal surface in three dimensions having a high symmetry. Materials with this structure can be realized on a nanoscale in the lab and are also found in nature on wings of butterflies. We made major contributions to understanding the band structure and its level crossings in terms of non-commutative geometry, singularity theory and group theory. These materials are promising candidates for increasing the effectiveness of solar cells. 

Lastly, our study of topological insulators allows the understanding of the bulk-boundary correspondence in terms of a mathematical index theorem. Topological insulators are materials that behave like insulators in the bulk but exhibit conducting edge states. It is believed that topological insulators can be used in the field of quantum computing. 

The broader impact of this work consists of the cross-fertilization of the different fields of mathematics and physics. The project involved the participation of underrepresented minorities. It has impact on the development of solar cells with higher effectiveness and also on the advancement of quantum computing. In the course of the project, both graduate and undergraduate students were involved, contributing significantly to the training aspect of the proposal. The results have been made widely available, the PI has given numerous talks both nationally and internationally about the results of the proposal and made all the publications available on her website and the arXiv.
